“I’ve come to inquire if you have work for me. That is, if.my performance pleased you before.” A deliberate prompt. I.didn’t want to be hired because of my need or his kindness. I.wanted my talent to be the reason he wanted me back..“Indeed” was all he offered..What now to fill the suspended moment? His new.projects. I asked. His eyebrows leapt up in symmetrical.curves..“A Byzantine chapel for the World’s Columbian.Exposition in Chicago next year. Four times bigger than the.Paris Exposition Universelle. It will be the greatest assembly.of artists since the fifteenth century.” He counted on his.fingers and then drummed them on the desk. “Only fifteen.months away. In 1893 the name of Louis Comfort Tiffany.will be on the lips of millions!” He stood up and swung open.his arms wide enough to embrace the whole world..I sensed his open palm somewhere in the air behind the.small of my back, ushering me to his massive, carved.mahogany exhibit table to see his sketches and watercolors..“Two round windows, The Infancy of Christ and Botticelli’s.Madonna and Child, will be set off by a dozen scenic side.windows.”.A huge undertaking. How richly fortunate. Surely there.would be opportunity for me to shine..Practically hopping from side to side, he made a show of.slinging down one large watercolor after another onto the.Persian carpet, each one a precise, fine-edged rendering of.what he wanted the window to be..“Gracious! You’ve been on fire. Go slower! Give me a.chance to admire each one.”.He unrolled the largest watercolor. “An eight-foot.mosaic behind the altar depicting a pair of peacocks.surrounded by grapevines.”.My breath whistled between my open lips. Above the.peacocks facing each other, he had transformed the.standard Christian icon of a crown of thorns into a.shimmering regal headdress for God the King, the thorns.replaced by large glass jewels in true Tiffany style..Astonishing how he could get mere watercolors so deep.and saturated, so like lacquer that they vibrated together as.surely as chords of a great church pipe organ. Even the.names of the hues bore an exotic richness. The peacocks’.necks in emerald green and sapphire blue. The tail feathers.in vermilion, Spanish ocher, Florida gold. The jewels in the.crown mandarin yellow and peridot. The background in.turquoise and cobalt. Oh, to get my hands on those.gorgeous hues. To feel the coolness of the blue glass, like.solid pieces of the sea. To chip the gigantic jewels for the.crown so they would sparkle and send out shafts of light..To forget everything but the glass before me and make of it.something resplendent..When I could trust my voice not to show too much.eagerness, I said, “I see your originality is in good health..Only you would put peacocks in a chapel.”.“Don’t you know?” he said in a spoof of incredulity..“They symbolized eternal life in Byzantine art. Their flesh.was thought to be incorruptible.”.“What a lucky find for you, that convenient tidbit of.information.”.He chuckled, so I was on safe ground..He tossed down more drawings. “A marble-and-mosaic.altar surrounded by mosaic columns, and a baptismal font.of opaque leaded glass and mosaic.”.“This dome is the lid of the basin? In opaque leaded.glass?”.He looked at it with nothing short of love, and showed.me its size with outstretched arms as though he were.hugging the thing..I was struck by a tantalizing idea. “Imagine it reduced in.size and made of translucent glass instead. Once you figure.how to secure the pieces in a dome, that could be the.method and the shape of a lampshade. A wraparound.window of, say”—I looked around the room—“peacock.feathers.”.He jerked his head up with a startled expression, the.idea dawning on him as if it were his own..“Lampshades in leaded glass,” he said in wonder, his.blue eyes sparking..“Just think where that could go,” I whispered.
Which choice best describes what happens in the passage?
(A)The narrator reflects on how the behavior of another character has changed.
(B)The narrator struggles to understand the motivations of another character.
(C)The narrator discusses shared professional interests with another character.
(D)The narrator recounts the events that led another character to support her project.
output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and identify the key events and interactions that occur.

The passage begins with the narrator inquiring about potential work from the other character. The narrator wants to be hired based on their talent rather than out of need or kindness. The other character responds simply with "Indeed."

The narrator then asks the other character about their new projects. The other character describes a large-scale project - a Byzantine chapel for the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago. He excitedly talks about the scale and artistry involved, including specific design elements like the stained glass windows.

The narrator is impressed by the project and sees it as an opportunity to showcase their own talents. The other character then shows the narrator his detailed watercolor sketches of the chapel's design, including the peacock motif. 

The narrator is captivated by the colors and design, and starts to envision how the stained glass elements could be further developed, such as into lampshades.

Based on this, the best choice is (C) The narrator discusses shared professional interests with another character. The passage focuses on the narrator and the other character discussing the artistic details and potential of the chapel project, demonstrating their shared interest in the work.

The passage does not indicate any changes in the other character's behavior (choice A), nor does it focus on the narrator struggling to understand the other character's motivations (choice B). The key events center around their collaborative professional discussion (choice C).

2. Tiffany mentions that the project will be "Four times bigger than the Paris Exposition Universelle" and "the greatest assembly of artists since the fifteenth century." This suggests that Tiffany views the Exposition as an opportunity to gain greater popular recognition and acclaim.

(D)displaying a chart that shows the placement of the artworks he plans to exhibit in Chicago.
output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage begins with the narrator inquiring if Tiffany has work for her, wanting her talent to be the reason he wants her back.

2. Tiffany responds with "Indeed", indicating that he does have work for her.

3. Tiffany then describes his new project - a Byzantine chapel for the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago the following year, which will be four times larger than the Paris Exposition Universelle.

4. Tiffany then starts showing the narrator a series of watercolor sketches and paintings for the windows and decorations of the chapel, including:
   - Two round windows depicting "The Infancy of Christ" and Botticelli's "Madonna and Child"
   - An 8-foot mosaic behind the altar depicting peacocks surrounded by grapevines, with a shimmering regal headdress for God the King
   - A marble-and-mosaic altar surrounded by mosaic columns, and a baptismal font of opaque leaded glass and mosaic

5. The narrator is clearly impressed by Tiffany's designs and watercolors, and even suggests the idea of making a lampshade out of translucent glass in the shape of peacock feathers.

Based on this, the correct answer is (B) Tiffany is presenting several finished stained glass window designs and describing them in detail.
question:
“I’ve come to inquire if you have work for me. That is, if.my performance pleased you before.” A deliberate prompt. I.didn’t want to be hired because of my need or his kindness. I.wanted my talent to be the reason he wanted me back..“Indeed” was all he offered..What now to fill the suspended moment? His new.projects. I asked. His eyebrows leapt up in symmetrical.curves..“A Byzantine chapel for the World’s Columbian.Exposition in Chicago next year. Four times bigger than the.Paris Exposition Universelle. It will be the greatest assembly.of artists since the fifteenth century.” He counted on his.fingers and then drummed them on the desk. “Only fifteen.months away. In 1893 the name of Louis Comfort Tiffany.will be on the lips of millions!” He stood up and swung open.his arms wide enough to embrace the whole world..I sensed his open palm somewhere in the air behind the.small of my back, ushering me to his massive, carved.mahogany exhibit table to see his sketches and watercolors..“Two round windows, The Infancy of Christ and Botticelli’s.Madonna and Child, will be set off by a dozen scenic side.windows.”.A huge undertaking. How richly fortunate. Surely there.would be opportunity for me to shine..Practically hopping from side to side, he made a show of.slinging down one large watercolor after another onto the.Persian carpet, each one a precise, fine-edged rendering of.what he wanted the window to be..“Gracious! You’ve been on fire. Go slower! Give me a.chance to admire each one.”.He unrolled the largest watercolor. “An eight-foot.mosaic behind the altar depicting a pair of peacocks.surrounded by grapevines.”.My breath whistled between my open lips. Above the.peacocks facing each other, he had transformed the.standard Christian icon of a crown of thorns into a.shimmering regal headdress for God the King, the thorns.replaced by large glass jewels in true Tiffany style..Astonishing how he could get mere watercolors so deep.and saturated, so like lacquer that they vibrated together as.surely as chords of a great church pipe organ. Even the.names of the hues bore an exotic richness. The peacocks’.necks in emerald green and sapphire blue. The tail feathers.in vermilion, Spanish ocher, Florida gold. The jewels in the.crown mandarin yellow and peridot. The background in.turquoise and cobalt. Oh, to get my hands on those.gorgeous hues. To feel the coolness of the blue glass, like.solid pieces of the sea. To chip the gigantic jewels for the.crown so they would sparkle and send out shafts of light..To forget everything but the glass before me and make of it.something resplendent..When I could trust my voice not to show too much.eagerness, I said, “I see your originality is in good health..Only you would put peacocks in a chapel.”.“Don’t you know?” he said in a spoof of incredulity..“They symbolized eternal life in Byzantine art. Their flesh.was thought to be incorruptible.”.“What a lucky find for you, that convenient tidbit of.information.”.He chuckled, so I was on safe ground..He tossed down more drawings. “A marble-and-mosaic.altar surrounded by mosaic columns, and a baptismal font.of opaque leaded glass and mosaic.”.“This dome is the lid of the basin? In opaque leaded.glass?”.He looked at it with nothing short of love, and showed.me its size with outstretched arms as though he were.hugging the thing..I was struck by a tantalizing idea. “Imagine it reduced in.size and made of translucent glass instead. Once you figure.how to secure the pieces in a dome, that could be the.method and the shape of a lampshade. A wraparound.window of, say”—I looked around the room—“peacock.feathers.”.He jerked his head up with a startled expression, the.idea dawning on him as if it were his own..“Lampshades in leaded glass,” he said in wonder, his.blue eyes sparking..“Just think where that could go,” I whispered.

(A)showing a series of plans for stained glass windows he intends to construct.
(B)presenting several finished stained glass windows and describing them in detail.
(C)asking her opinion of the watercolor paintings he plans to exhibit in Chicago.
(D)displaying a chart that shows the placement of the artworks he plans to exhibit in Chicago.

solve_prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
A pair of recent studies suggests that although.industrialized nations may have benefitted from larger.cities, the same is not true for the rapidly urbanizing areas of.the developing world. In these parts of the globe, there really.might be such a thing as too much urbanization, too.quickly..The studies, by Susanne A. Frick and Andrés Rodríguez-.Pose of the London School of Economics, take a close look.at the actual connection between city size and nationwide.economic performance. Their initial study, from last year,.examines the relationship between economic development,.as measured by GDP per capita, and average metropolitan-.area size in 114 countries across the world between 1960.and 2010. To ensure robustness, it controls for variables.including national population size, physical land area,.education levels, economic openness, and other factors..The size of cities or metro areas across the world has.exploded over the past half-century, with cities in the.developing world growing much faster and much larger.than those in more developed nations. Between 1960 and 2010, the median city in high-income countries grew.modestly from 500,000 to 650,000 people; but the median.city in the developing world nearly quadrupled, expanding.from 220,000 to 845,000 people. In 1960, 12 of the top 20.countries with the largest average city size were high-.income countries; by 2010, 14 of the top 20 were in the.developing world..Urbanization has historically been thought of as a.necessary feature of economic development and growth, but.this study finds the connection is not so simple. While.advanced nations benefit from having larger cities,.developing nations do not. Advanced nations experience a 0.7 percent increase in economic growth for every.additional 100,000 in average population among its large.cities over a five-year period. But for developing nations, the.addition of 100,000 people in large cities is associated with a 2.3 percent decrease in economic growth over a five-year.period..In their latest study, the researchers found that.developing nations tend to get a bigger bang for their buck.from smaller and medium-size cities. These countries see.the most economic benefit from having a larger proportion.of their urban population living in cities of 500,000 people.or less. Bigger cities tend to have a more positive economic.impact in larger countries. Having a metro with more than 10 million inhabitants produces a nationwide economic.benefit only if the total urban population is 28.5 million.or more, according to the study. This makes sense:.Bigger, more developed countries are more likely to play.host to knowledge-based industries that require urban.agglomeration economies..There are several reasons why megacities^1 often fail to.spur significant growth in the rapidly urbanizing world..For one, the lion’s share of places that are urbanizing.most rapidly today are in the poorest and least-.developed parts of the world, whereas the places that.urbanized a century or so ago were in the richest and.most developed. This history has created a false.expectation that urbanization is always associated with.prosperity..Additionally, globalization has severed the historical.connection between cities, local agriculture, and local.industry that powered the more balanced urban.economic development of the past. In today’s globally.interconnected economy, the raw materials that flowed.from the surrounding countryside to the city can all be.inexpensively imported from other parts of the world..The result is that the connection between large cities and.growth has now become much more tenuous, producing.a troubling new pattern of “urbanization without.growth.”.The researchers used multiple variables to calculate a weighted average.city size for each country studied and reported the median of those.averages..(^1) Typically defined as cities with populations of over ten million people
The main purpose of the passage is to
(A)describe the causes and consequences of a phenomenon.
(B)propose a new solution to an ongoing problem.
(C)question whether recent research has practical applications.
(D)critique the methodology used to arrive at new findings.
output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and identify the main purpose.

The passage discusses two recent studies that examine the relationship between city size and economic performance in both developed and developing countries. 

The key points are:
1. Urbanization has increased significantly over the past 50 years, with much faster growth in developing countries compared to developed countries.
2. The studies found that while larger cities benefit the economies of developed nations, the same is not true for developing nations. In fact, the studies found that rapid urbanization and very large cities in developing countries are associated with decreased economic growth.
3. The researchers suggest that developing countries tend to benefit more economically from smaller and medium-sized cities rather than megacities.
4. The passage discusses several reasons why megacities may not spur economic growth in rapidly urbanizing parts of the developing world.

Based on this, the main purpose of the passage is to (A) describe the causes and consequences of a phenomenon - the relationship between city size and economic performance, particularly in the context of rapid urbanization in the developing world.

The passage does not propose a new solution (B), question the practical applications of recent research (C), or critique the methodology used (D). Rather, it summarizes the key findings of two recent studies on this topic.

Based on the passage, which choice best describesthe relationship between Frick and Rodríguez-Pose’sfirst and second studies?
(A)The second study corrects a minor error in the research of the first study.
(B)The second study confirms a hypothesis that they were unable to confirm in the first study.

(D)The second study offers a more negative interpretation of a recent event than the first study does.

To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage describes two recent studies by Susanne A. Frick and Andrés Rodríguez-Pose of the London School of Economics.

2. The first study, from last year, examines the relationship between economic development (measured by GDP per capita) and average metropolitan area size in 114 countries from 1960 to 2010.

3. The key findings of the first study are:
- The size of cities/metro areas has exploded over the past half-century, with faster growth in developing countries.
- While advanced nations benefit from having larger cities, developing nations do not. Advanced nations see a 0.7% increase in economic growth for every 100,000 increase in average city population, but developing nations see a 2.3% decrease.

4. The second study by the same researchers found that developing nations tend to get more economic benefit from smaller and medium-size cities (500,000 people or less). Bigger cities only have a positive economic impact in larger, more developed countries.

5. Based on this, the relationship between the first and second studies is best described as the second study building on the findings of the first study. The second study provides a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between city size and economic performance in developing countries, building on the initial findings from the first study.

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) The second study builds on the first study's findings.

   - These places are in the poorest and least-developed parts of the world, unlike the rich and developed countries that urbanized a century ago.

The passage does not provide enough information to conclude that a megacity's impact is greater in countries with larger physical land areas (option A) or that the impact is relatively equal for developing and high-income countries (option C). It also does not suggest that the economic cost of maintaining a megacity neutralizes its impact (option D).

Therefore, the correct answer is B.

The key difference between the two passages is:

(D) Passage 1 focuses on small-scale genetic changes (the NOTCH2NL gene) that influenced brain evolution, while Passage 2 focuses on the influence of large-scale population-level changes (evolution of larger brains within species, introduction of new larger-brained species, and extinction of smaller-brained ones).

Passage 1 delves into the specific genetic mechanisms that may have contributed to the increase in human brain size, while Passage 2 takes a broader, population-level perspective on the factors that led to the gradual increase in average brain size over a much longer timeframe.

Therefore, the correct answer is (D).

That all.changed with the next official version of the human.genome—version 38. In this iteration, NOTCH2NL was.located in the crucial region. “And there were three.versions of it,” Haussler exclaimed. Over the last three.million years, his team calculated, NOTCH2NL was.repeatedly copy-pasted into the genome, what he calls “a.series of genetic accidents.”.Genetic analysis of several primate species revealed that.the three genes exist only in humans and their recent.relatives, the Neanderthals and Denisovans, not in.chimpanzees, gorillas, or orangutans. What’s more, the.timing of these genes’ emergence matches up with the.period in the fossil record when our ancestors’ craniums.began to enlarge, Haussler points out. Together, the results.suggest that NOTCH2NL genes played a role in beefing.up human brain size..Passage 2.Modern humans have brains that are more than three.times larger than our closest living relatives,.chimpanzees and bonobos. Scientists don’t agree on.when and how this dramatic increase took place, but.new analysis of 94 hominin fossils shows that average.brain size increased gradually and consistently over the.past three million years..The research, published in The Proceedings of the.Royal Society B, shows that the trend was caused.primarily by evolution of larger brains within.populations of individual species, but the introduction of.new, larger-brained species and extinction of smaller-.brained ones also played a part..“Brain size is one of the most obvious traits that.makes us human. It’s related to cultural complexity,.language, tool making and all these other things that.make us unique,” said Andrew Du, PhD, a postdoctoral.scholar at the University of Chicago and first author of.the study. “The earliest hominins had brain sizes like.chimpanzees, and they have increased dramatically since.then. So, it’s important to understand how we got here.”.Du and his colleagues compared published research.data on the skull volumes of 94 fossil specimens from 13.different species, beginning with the earliest.unambiguous human ancestors, Australopithecus, from 3.2 million years ago to pre-modern species, including.Homo erectus, from 500,000 years ago when brain size.began to overlap with that of modern-day humans..The researchers saw that when the species were.counted at the clade level, or groups descending from a.common ancestor, the average brain size increased.gradually over three million years. Looking more closely,.the increase was driven by three different factors,.primarily evolution of larger brain sizes within.individual species populations, but also by the addition.of new, larger-brained species and extinction of smaller-.brained ones..The study quantifies for the first time when and by.how much each of these factors contributes to the clade-.level pattern. Du said he likens it to how a football coach.might build a roster of bigger, strong players. One way.would be to make all the players hit the weight room to.bulk up. But the coach could also recruit new, larger.players and cut the smallest ones..(^1) The reference version of the human genome goes through updates to.more completely map out each chromosomal sequence.
Both passages state that the modern human brain is about three times larger than the brains of
(A)bonobos.
(B)chimpanzees.
(C)early hominins.
(D)Neanderthals.
output:

1. Passage 1 states that the human brain is "conspicuously larger than the brains of other apes", and that "humans split from chimps, which have brains roughly a third of human size".

2. Passage 2 also states that "Modern humans have brains that are more than three times larger than our closest living relatives, chimpanzees and bonobos."

3. Based on this information, the correct answer is (B) chimpanzees.

The passages clearly state that the modern human brain is around 3 times larger than the brains of chimpanzees, our closest living relatives. They do not mention bonobos, early hominins, or Neanderthals in this specific comparison.

solve_prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
For too long now, we have heard it argued that a focus.on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples’ rights.takes away from a focus on addressing Aboriginal and.Torres Strait Islander peoples’ disadvantage..This approach is, in my view, seriously flawed for a.number of reasons. It represents a false dichotomy—as if.poorer standards of health, lack of access to housing,.lower attainment in education and higher unemployment.are not human rights issues or somehow they don’t relate.to the cultural circumstances of Indigenous peoples..And it also makes it too easy to disguise any causal.relationship between the actions of government and any.outcomes, and therefore limits the accountability and.responsibilities of government..In contrast, human rights give Aboriginal and Torres.Strait Islander peoples a means for expressing their.legitimate claims to equal goods, services, and most.importantly, the protections of the law—and a standard.that government is required to measure up to..The focus on ‘practical measures’ was exemplified by.the emphasis the previous federal government placed on.the ‘record levels of expenditure’ annually on Indigenous.issues..As I have previously asked, since when did the size of.the input become more important than the intended.outcomes? The... government never explained what the.point of the record expenditure argument was—or what.achievements were made.....And the fact is that there has been no simple way of.being able to decide whether the progress made through.‘record expenditure’ has been ‘good enough’. So the.‘practical’ approach to these issues has lacked any.accountability whatsoever.....If we look back over the past five years in particular....we can also see that a ‘practical’ approach to issues has.allowed governments to devise a whole series of policies.and programs without engaging with Indigenous peoples.in any serious manner. I have previously described this as.the ‘fundamental flaw’ of the federal government’s efforts.over the past five years. That is, government policy that is.applied to Indigenous peoples as passive recipients..Our challenge now is to redefine and understand these.issues as human rights issues..We face a major challenge in ‘skilling up’ government.and the bureaucracy so that they are capable of utilising.human rights as a tool for best practice policy.development and as an accountability mechanism..... In March this year, the Prime Minister, the Leader.of the Opposition, Ministers for Health and Indigenous.Affairs, every major Indigenous and non-Indigenous.peak health body and others signed a Statement of Intent.to close the gap in health inequality which set out how.this commitment would be met. It commits all of these.organisations and government, among other things, to:.- develop a long-term plan of action, that is targeted.to need, evidence-based and capable of addressing.the existing inequities in health services, in order to.achieve equality of health status and life expectancy.between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander.peoples and non-Indigenous Australians by 2030..- ensure the full participation of Aboriginal and.Torres Strait Islander peoples and their.representative bodies in all aspects of addressing.their health needs..- work collectively to systematically address the social.determinants that impact on achieving health.equality for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander.peoples..- respect and promote the rights of Aboriginal and.Torres Strait Islander peoples, and.- measure, monitor, and report on our joint efforts,.in accordance with benchmarks and targets, to.ensure that we are progressively realising our.shared ambitions..These commitments were made in relation to.Indigenous health issues but they form a template for the.type of approach that is needed across all areas of.poverty, marginalisation and disadvantage experienced.by Indigenous peoples..They provide the basis for the cultural shift necessary.in how we conceptualise human rights in this country..Issues of entrenched and ongoing poverty and.marginalisation of Indigenous peoples are human rights.challenges. And we need to lift our expectations of what.needs to be done to address these issues and of what.constitutes sufficient progress to address these issues in.the shortest possible timeframe so that we can realise a.vision of an equal society.
One central theme of the passage is that
(A)expanding legal rights of citizens will not necessarily improve national health outcomes.
(B)human rights initiatives should generally receive more funding than health initiatives do.
(C)human rights should be used as a framework for government policy on indigenous issues.
(D)focusing on indigenous peoples’ rights detracts from the more practical concerns of indigenous communities.
output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and analyze the central theme.

The passage starts by criticizing the view that "a focus on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' rights takes away from a focus on addressing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' disadvantage." The author argues that this is a "false dichotomy" and that issues like poor health, lack of housing, and unemployment are in fact human rights issues.

The author then critiques the previous government's emphasis on "record levels of expenditure" on indigenous issues, arguing that the size of input is less important than the intended outcomes. The author states that this "practical" approach has lacked accountability.

The author then says that the challenge now is to "redefine and understand these issues as human rights issues" and to "skill up" the government and bureaucracy to use human rights as a tool for policy development and accountability.

In the final section, the author discusses a "Statement of Intent" signed by the Prime Minister, Opposition Leader, and various organizations, which commits to developing a long-term plan to achieve health equality, ensure indigenous participation, address social determinants, and respect indigenous rights.

The central theme that emerges from this passage is that (C) human rights should be used as a framework for government policy on indigenous issues. The author argues strongly against the "practical" approach that divorces indigenous issues from human rights, and advocates for framing them explicitly through a human rights lens.

The passage does not support the other answer choices. It does not suggest that expanding legal rights will not improve health outcomes (A), nor that human rights initiatives should generally receive more funding than health initiatives (B). It directly contradicts the idea that focusing on indigenous rights detracts from more practical concerns (D).

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) human rights should be used as a framework for government policy on indigenous issues.

According to Calma, the government’s failure tolink its expenditures on indigenous health initiativesto specific health outcomes is harmful because it
(A)reinforces negative attitudes about the government’s financial fitness.
(B)undermines efforts to standardize practices across all departments of the government.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage discusses the issues surrounding the focus on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' rights versus addressing their disadvantage. 

2. The author argues that this is a false dichotomy, as the poorer standards of health, lack of access to housing, lower education attainment, and higher unemployment are human rights issues connected to the cultural circumstances of Indigenous peoples.

3. The author criticizes the previous government's focus on "practical measures" and "record levels of expenditure" on Indigenous issues, arguing that the size of the input is less important than the intended outcomes.

4. The author states that this "practical" approach has lacked any real accountability, as there was no way to determine if the progress made was "good enough".

5. The author then discusses a Statement of Intent signed in 2020 to close the gap in health inequality between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. This commits the government and other organizations to develop a long-term action plan, ensure full participation of Indigenous peoples, address social determinants of health, and measure and report on progress.

6. The key point is that the author believes the government's failure to link its expenditures on Indigenous health initiatives to specific health outcomes perpetuates a lack of accountability.

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) - it allows the government to evade the obligation to be answerable for its policies.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the text step-by-step:

1. The passage discusses how in the past, there has been a focus on "practical measures" and "record levels of expenditure" on indigenous issues, rather than on addressing the fundamental human rights of indigenous peoples.

2. Specifically, the passage states that the previous federal government emphasized the "record levels of expenditure" annually on indigenous issues, as if the size of the input (funding) was more important than the intended outcomes.

3. The passage argues that this "practical" approach has lacked accountability, as there has been no clear way to determine if the "progress made through 'record expenditure'" has been "good enough".

4. So the key aspect that the passage indicates the Australian government has stressed in the past is the financial resources it has devoted to indigenous issues, rather than the actual outcomes and progress in addressing indigenous peoples' rights and disadvantages.

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) The financial resources it has devoted to indigenous issues.
question:
For too long now, we have heard it argued that a focus.on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples’ rights.takes away from a focus on addressing Aboriginal and.Torres Strait Islander peoples’ disadvantage..This approach is, in my view, seriously flawed for a.number of reasons. It represents a false dichotomy—as if.poorer standards of health, lack of access to housing,.lower attainment in education and higher unemployment.are not human rights issues or somehow they don’t relate.to the cultural circumstances of Indigenous peoples..And it also makes it too easy to disguise any causal.relationship between the actions of government and any.outcomes, and therefore limits the accountability and.responsibilities of government..In contrast, human rights give Aboriginal and Torres.Strait Islander peoples a means for expressing their.legitimate claims to equal goods, services, and most.importantly, the protections of the law—and a standard.that government is required to measure up to..The focus on ‘practical measures’ was exemplified by.the emphasis the previous federal government placed on.the ‘record levels of expenditure’ annually on Indigenous.issues..As I have previously asked, since when did the size of.the input become more important than the intended.outcomes? The... government never explained what the.point of the record expenditure argument was—or what.achievements were made.....And the fact is that there has been no simple way of.being able to decide whether the progress made through.‘record expenditure’ has been ‘good enough’. So the.‘practical’ approach to these issues has lacked any.accountability whatsoever.....If we look back over the past five years in particular....we can also see that a ‘practical’ approach to issues has.allowed governments to devise a whole series of policies.and programs without engaging with Indigenous peoples.in any serious manner. I have previously described this as.the ‘fundamental flaw’ of the federal government’s efforts.over the past five years. That is, government policy that is.applied to Indigenous peoples as passive recipients..Our challenge now is to redefine and understand these.issues as human rights issues..We face a major challenge in ‘skilling up’ government.and the bureaucracy so that they are capable of utilising.human rights as a tool for best practice policy.development and as an accountability mechanism..... In March this year, the Prime Minister, the Leader.of the Opposition, Ministers for Health and Indigenous.Affairs, every major Indigenous and non-Indigenous.peak health body and others signed a Statement of Intent.to close the gap in health inequality which set out how.this commitment would be met. It commits all of these.organisations and government, among other things, to:.- develop a long-term plan of action, that is targeted.to need, evidence-based and capable of addressing.the existing inequities in health services, in order to.achieve equality of health status and life expectancy.between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander.peoples and non-Indigenous Australians by 2030..- ensure the full participation of Aboriginal and.Torres Strait Islander peoples and their.representative bodies in all aspects of addressing.their health needs..- work collectively to systematically address the social.determinants that impact on achieving health.equality for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander.peoples..- respect and promote the rights of Aboriginal and.Torres Strait Islander peoples, and.- measure, monitor, and report on our joint efforts,.in accordance with benchmarks and targets, to.ensure that we are progressively realising our.shared ambitions..These commitments were made in relation to.Indigenous health issues but they form a template for the.type of approach that is needed across all areas of.poverty, marginalisation and disadvantage experienced.by Indigenous peoples..They provide the basis for the cultural shift necessary.in how we conceptualise human rights in this country..Issues of entrenched and ongoing poverty and.marginalisation of Indigenous peoples are human rights.challenges. And we need to lift our expectations of what.needs to be done to address these issues and of what.constitutes sufficient progress to address these issues in.the shortest possible timeframe so that we can realise a.vision of an equal society.
Calma indicates that in the past, the Australiangovernment stressed which aspect of its relationshipto indigenous peoples?
(A)The willingness it has shown to meet with indigenous leaders
(B)The regret it has expressed for the injustices it committed against indigenous peoples
(C)The improvements it has made in indigenous peoples’ living standards
(D)The financial resources it has devoted to indigenous issues

(A)empowered indigenous communities to assist in devising and implementing such programs.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and identify the key points that are relevant to answering the question.

The passage argues that the focus on "practical measures" and "record levels of expenditure" on indigenous issues has been flawed, as it lacks accountability and engagement with indigenous peoples. The author, Calma, argues that these issues should be framed as human rights challenges, and that the government needs to work with indigenous communities to develop and implement effective policies.

Specifically, the passage highlights the "Statement of Intent" signed in March this year, which commits the government and other organizations to:
- Develop a long-term plan of action, with the full participation of indigenous peoples, to achieve equality in health status and life expectancy.
- Respect and promote the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.
- Measure, monitor, and report on their efforts to realize these shared ambitions.

Based on this, the passage indicates that Calma would most likely agree that programs related to indigenous issues would have a better chance of succeeding if the Australian government:

(A) empowered indigenous communities to assist in devising and implementing such programs.
This is directly supported by the passage, which highlights the need for "the full participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and their representative bodies in all aspects of addressing their health needs."

The other options are not as strongly supported:
(B) is not specifically mentioned, and the passage focuses more on the need for accountability and engagement rather than funding levels.
(C) is not discussed in the passage.
(D) the passage criticizes the previous government's focus on "record levels of expenditure" without accompanying progress or accountability.

Therefore, the answer that is best supported by the passage is (A).

(A)skeptical that the specific individuals responsible for the government’s failed policies on indigenous issues will be held accountable.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage discusses the argument that a focus on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' rights takes away from a focus on addressing their disadvantage. Calma argues that this is a false dichotomy - issues of poor health, lack of housing, low education, and high unemployment are human rights issues related to the cultural circumstances of Indigenous peoples.

2. Calma criticizes the previous government's emphasis on "record levels of expenditure" on Indigenous issues, arguing that the size of the input is less important than the intended outcomes. He says there has been no accountability for whether the progress made through this expenditure has been "good enough".

3. Calma states that a "practical" approach has allowed the government to devise policies and programs without engaging with Indigenous peoples in a serious manner, treating them as "passive recipients".

4. Calma argues that these issues need to be reframed as human rights issues, and that there is a challenge in "skilling up" the government and bureaucracy to use human rights as a tool for policy development and accountability.

5. Calma points to the Statement of Intent signed by the Prime Minister, Opposition Leader, and others, which commits to developing a long-term plan, ensuring full participation of Indigenous peoples, addressing social determinants, respecting and promoting rights, and measuring and reporting on joint efforts.

Based on this, the passage suggests that Calma regards the audience as being:

(C) Doubtful of the value of discussing indigenous issues within the larger context of human rights.

The passage indicates that Calma is arguing against this view, and trying to reframe indigenous issues as human rights challenges that require a different approach from the government. He is attempting to shift the audience's perspective on this.

solve_prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Scientists believe that iron meteorites come from.the cores of asteroids that melted. But what happened.to the corresponding rocky material that formed the.mantles of these bodies? A few asteroids have spectra^1.that match those of mantle rocks, but they are very.rare. Some nonmetallic meteorites come from.asteroids that have partially or wholly melted, but.these do not match the minerals we would expect to.see in the missing mantles of the iron parent bodies..These exotic meteorites must come from some other.kind of parent body instead..The rarity of mantle rocks in our meteorite.collection and in the asteroid belt, known as the.“missing mantle problem,” is a long-standing puzzle..There are several reasons why iron fragments might.survive better than rocky fragments when asteroids.break apart. Iron lies in the core of a differentiated.asteroid, while rocky material lies near the surface..Thus, rocky material will be the first to be removed.when an asteroid is bombarded, while iron is the last.to be exposed. As a result, rocky fragments have to.survive in space for longer than iron ones. Most of the.rocky mantle may be peeled away in small fragments.—chips from the surface—while the iron core remains.as a single piece, making it harder to disrupt later. Last.and most important, iron is much stronger than rock:.a piece of iron is likely to survive in the asteroid belt at.least 10 times longer than a rocky fragment of the.same size..If most differentiated bodies broke apart early in.the solar system, perhaps all the mantle material has.been ground down to dust and lost over the billions of.years since then. This would mean that intact.differentiated asteroids are very rare in the asteroid.belt today. Perhaps Vesta [a differentiated asteroid.with a diameter of more than 300 miles] and a handful.of others are all that remain..However, collisional erosion cannot be the whole.story. Primitive asteroids, the parent bodies of.chondritic meteorites [the most common type of.meteorite found on Earth], are no stronger than the.mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids. How did.so many primitive asteroids survive when almost.none of the differentiated ones did? Part of the.explanation may simply be that differentiated bodies.were relatively rare to begin with and none have.survived. Still, if almost all differentiated bodies were.destroyed in violent collisions, how did Vesta survive.with only a single large crater on its surface?.Astronomer William Bottke and his colleagues.recently came up with a possible explanation: perhaps.the parent bodies of the iron meteorites formed closer.to the Sun, in the region that now contains the.terrestrial planets. Objects would have been more.tightly packed nearer the Sun, so collisions would.have been more frequent than in the asteroid belt..Many, perhaps most, differentiated bodies were.disrupted by violent collisions. Gravitational.perturbations from larger bodies scattered some of.these fragments into the asteroid belt. Both iron and.rocky fragments arrived in the asteroid belt, but only.the stronger iron objects have survived for the age of.the solar system. Later on, the parent bodies of.primitive meteorites formed in the asteroid belt. Most.of these objects survived, leaving an asteroid belt.today that is a mixture of intact primitive bodies and.fragments of iron..(^1) Characteristic wavelengths of light that asteroids reflect
The main purpose of the passage is to
(A)discuss a study intended to explain the high number of meteorites on Earth that have come from primitive asteroids.
(B)describe competing hypotheses about the conditions under which primitive asteroids initially formed.
(C)present a scientific debate about the prevalence of differentiated asteroids in the asteroid belt in the early solar system.
(D)account for the scarcity of a component of differentiated asteroids in the asteroid belt and among meteorites on Earth.
output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and identify the key information that answers the question.

The main question is about the purpose of the passage. The passage discusses the "missing mantle problem" - the rarity of mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids in the asteroid belt and among meteorites on Earth.

The passage presents several hypotheses to explain this phenomenon:
1) Iron fragments survive better than rocky fragments when asteroids break apart, since iron is in the core while rocky material is on the surface.
2) Most differentiated bodies broke apart early in the solar system, and the mantle material was ground down to dust over time.
3) Differentiated bodies may have formed closer to the Sun, where collisions were more frequent, and most were disrupted. The stronger iron fragments then scattered into the asteroid belt.
4) Primitive asteroids, the parent bodies of chondritic meteorites, were able to survive better than the differentiated asteroids.

The passage is clearly focused on explaining the "missing mantle problem" and the various hypotheses that scientists have proposed to account for the scarcity of mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids. 

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) - the passage is intended to account for the scarcity of a component of differentiated asteroids in the asteroid belt and among meteorites on Earth.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and identify the key information that is relevant to answering the question.

The passage discusses the "missing mantle problem" - the rarity of mantle rocks in the meteorite collection and the asteroid belt, compared to the abundance of iron meteorites that scientists believe come from the cores of differentiated asteroids.

The passage presents several reasons why iron fragments might survive better than rocky fragments when asteroids break apart:
1. Iron lies in the core of a differentiated asteroid, while rocky material lies near the surface. So rocky material will be the first to be removed.
2. Rocky fragments have to survive in space for longer than iron ones, as the rocky mantle may be peeled away in small fragments.
3. Iron is much stronger than rock, so a piece of iron is likely to survive in the asteroid belt at least 10 times longer than a rocky fragment of the same size.

The passage then suggests that if most differentiated bodies broke apart early in the solar system, perhaps all the mantle material has been ground down to dust and lost over the billions of years since then. This would mean that intact differentiated asteroids are very rare in the asteroid belt today.

The passage then raises the question of how so many primitive asteroids (the parent bodies of chondritic meteorites) survived when almost none of the differentiated ones did. It suggests that perhaps the parent bodies of the iron meteorites formed closer to the Sun, where collisions would have been more frequent, and many differentiated bodies were disrupted by violent collisions. Gravitational perturbations from larger bodies then scattered some of these fragments into the asteroid belt.

Now, to answer the question:
The passage most strongly suggests that if collisional erosion within the asteroid belt was sufficient to explain the situation discussed in the passage, then scientists would expect to find that there were originally about as many primitive asteroids as differentiated asteroids in the asteroid belt.

This is because the passage suggests that the survival of primitive asteroids is a puzzle, since they are no stronger than the mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids. If collisional erosion was the sole explanation, then scientists would expect to find that primitive asteroids also suffered high rates of destruction, similar to the differentiated asteroids. The passage implies that the survival of so many primitive asteroids is at odds with the destruction of the differentiated asteroids, suggesting that the original populations were similar.

Therefore, the correct answer is (D).

To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage states that scientists believe iron meteorites come from the cores of asteroids that melted, but the corresponding rocky material that formed the mantles of these bodies is missing.

2. The passage explains that a few asteroids have spectra that match mantle rocks, but they are very rare. Some non-metallic meteorites come from asteroids that have partially or wholly melted, but they do not match the minerals expected in the missing mantles.

3. The passage states that this "missing mantle problem" is a long-standing puzzle. There are several reasons why iron fragments might survive better than rocky fragments when asteroids break apart:
- Iron lies in the core of a differentiated asteroid, while rocky material lies near the surface. So rocky material will be the first to be removed when an asteroid is bombarded.
- Rocky fragments have to survive in space for longer than iron ones. Most of the rocky mantle may be peeled away in small fragments, while the iron core remains as a single piece.
- Iron is much stronger than rock, so a piece of iron is likely to survive in the asteroid belt at least 10 times longer than a rocky fragment of the same size.

4. The passage suggests that if most differentiated bodies broke apart early in the solar system, all the mantle material may have been ground down to dust and lost over time. This would mean that intact differentiated asteroids are very rare in the asteroid belt today.

5. However, the passage notes that collisional erosion cannot be the whole story, as primitive asteroids (the parent bodies of chondritic meteorites) are no stronger than the mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids, yet many have survived.

6. Bottke and his colleagues propose a possible explanation: the parent bodies of the iron meteorites formed closer to the Sun, in the region that now contains the terrestrial planets. Collisions would have been more frequent in this region, disrupting many differentiated bodies. Some of these fragments were then scattered into the asteroid belt by gravitational perturbations from larger bodies.

Based on this, the correct answer is (B) - the fragments were created relatively close to the Sun and ended up in the asteroid belt due to the gravity of large objects.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the information provided step-by-step:

1. Scientists believe that iron meteorites come from the cores of asteroids that melted.

2. The problem is about what happened to the corresponding rocky material that formed the mantles of these bodies.

3. A few asteroids have spectra that match those of mantle rocks, but they are very rare.

4. Some nonmetallic meteorites come from asteroids that have partially or wholly melted, but these do not match the minerals we would expect to see in the missing mantles of the iron parent bodies.

5. The rarity of mantle rocks in the meteorite collection and in the asteroid belt is known as the "missing mantle problem".

6. There are several reasons why iron fragments might survive better than rocky fragments when asteroids break apart:
   - Iron lies in the core of a differentiated asteroid, while rocky material lies near the surface.
   - Rocky material will be the first to be removed when an asteroid is bombarded, while iron is the last to be exposed.
   - Rocky fragments have to survive in space for longer than iron ones.
   - Most of the rocky mantle may be peeled away in small fragments, while the iron core remains as a single piece.
   - Iron is much stronger than rock, and a piece of iron is likely to survive in the asteroid belt at least 10 times longer than a rocky fragment of the same size.

7. If most differentiated bodies broke apart early in the solar system, perhaps all the mantle material has been ground down to dust and lost over the billions of years since then. This would mean that intact differentiated asteroids are very rare in the asteroid belt today.

8. Collisional erosion cannot be the whole story, as primitive asteroids, the parent bodies of chondritic meteorites, are no stronger than the mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids. Yet, many primitive asteroids have survived when almost none of the differentiated ones did.

9. One possible explanation is that the parent bodies of the iron meteorites formed closer to the Sun, in the region that now contains the terrestrial planets. Collisions would have been more frequent in this region, disrupting many of the differentiated bodies, but the stronger iron objects have survived for the age of the solar system.

10. Later on, the parent bodies of primitive meteorites formed in the asteroid belt, and most of these objects survived, leaving an asteroid belt today that is a mixture of intact primitive bodies and fragments of iron.

Based on this information, the data in the table best support the conclusion that the majority of the mass in the asteroid belt as a whole is in asteroids that are primitive (option A). The passage states that most of the differentiated bodies were disrupted, while the primitive asteroids were able to survive, leaving the asteroid belt today as a mixture of intact primitive bodies and fragments of iron.

The passage discusses the "missing mantle problem" - the rarity of mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids in the meteorite collection and the asteroid belt. It suggests several reasons why iron fragments might survive better than rocky fragments when asteroids break apart.

Step 2: Identify the key information
The passage states that:
- Iron lies in the core of a differentiated asteroid, while rocky material lies near the surface.
- Rocky material will be the first to be removed when an asteroid is bombarded, while iron is the last to be exposed.
- Iron is much stronger than rock, and a piece of iron is likely to survive in the asteroid belt at least 10 times longer than a rocky fragment of the same size.
- Primitive asteroids, the parent bodies of chondritic meteorites, are no stronger than the mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids, yet many of them have survived.
- The passage suggests that perhaps the parent bodies of the iron meteorites formed closer to the Sun, where collisions would have been more frequent, and that many differentiated bodies were disrupted by violent collisions, with their fragments scattered into the asteroid belt.

Step 3: Analyze the statement options
(A) None of them is type V.
This statement is not supported by the information provided in the passage. The passage does not mention the types of asteroids that the four largest asteroid belt objects might be.

(B) None of them is likely to contain carbon.
This statement is not supported by the information provided in the passage. The passage does not mention the composition of the four largest asteroid belt objects.

(C) One of them is type K.
This statement is not supported by the information provided in the passage. The passage does not specify the types of asteroids that the four largest asteroid belt objects might be.

question:
Scientists believe that iron meteorites come from.the cores of asteroids that melted. But what happened.to the corresponding rocky material that formed the.mantles of these bodies? A few asteroids have spectra^1.that match those of mantle rocks, but they are very.rare. Some nonmetallic meteorites come from.asteroids that have partially or wholly melted, but.these do not match the minerals we would expect to.see in the missing mantles of the iron parent bodies..These exotic meteorites must come from some other.kind of parent body instead..The rarity of mantle rocks in our meteorite.collection and in the asteroid belt, known as the.“missing mantle problem,” is a long-standing puzzle..There are several reasons why iron fragments might.survive better than rocky fragments when asteroids.break apart. Iron lies in the core of a differentiated.asteroid, while rocky material lies near the surface..Thus, rocky material will be the first to be removed.when an asteroid is bombarded, while iron is the last.to be exposed. As a result, rocky fragments have to.survive in space for longer than iron ones. Most of the.rocky mantle may be peeled away in small fragments.—chips from the surface—while the iron core remains.as a single piece, making it harder to disrupt later. Last.and most important, iron is much stronger than rock:.a piece of iron is likely to survive in the asteroid belt at.least 10 times longer than a rocky fragment of the.same size..If most differentiated bodies broke apart early in.the solar system, perhaps all the mantle material has.been ground down to dust and lost over the billions of.years since then. This would mean that intact.differentiated asteroids are very rare in the asteroid.belt today. Perhaps Vesta [a differentiated asteroid.with a diameter of more than 300 miles] and a handful.of others are all that remain..However, collisional erosion cannot be the whole.story. Primitive asteroids, the parent bodies of.chondritic meteorites [the most common type of.meteorite found on Earth], are no stronger than the.mantle rocks from differentiated asteroids. How did.so many primitive asteroids survive when almost.none of the differentiated ones did? Part of the.explanation may simply be that differentiated bodies.were relatively rare to begin with and none have.survived. Still, if almost all differentiated bodies were.destroyed in violent collisions, how did Vesta survive.with only a single large crater on its surface?.Astronomer William Bottke and his colleagues.recently came up with a possible explanation: perhaps.the parent bodies of the iron meteorites formed closer.to the Sun, in the region that now contains the.terrestrial planets. Objects would have been more.tightly packed nearer the Sun, so collisions would.have been more frequent than in the asteroid belt..Many, perhaps most, differentiated bodies were.disrupted by violent collisions. Gravitational.perturbations from larger bodies scattered some of.these fragments into the asteroid belt. Both iron and.rocky fragments arrived in the asteroid belt, but only.the stronger iron objects have survived for the age of.the solar system. Later on, the parent bodies of.primitive meteorites formed in the asteroid belt. Most.of these objects survived, leaving an asteroid belt.today that is a mixture of intact primitive bodies and.fragments of iron..(^1) Characteristic wavelengths of light that asteroids reflect

solve_prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Eight years before he had seen his friend off at the.North Wall and wished him godspeed. Gallaher had.got on. You could tell that at once by his travelled air,.his well-cut tweed suit, and fearless accent. Few.fellows had talents like his and fewer still could.remain unspoiled by such success. Gallaher’s heart.was in the right place and he had deserved to win. It.was something to have a friend like that..Little Chandler’s thoughts ever since lunch-time.had been of his meeting with Gallaher, of Gallaher’s.invitation and of the great city of London where.Gallaher lived. He was called Little Chandler because,.though he was but slightly under the average stature,.he gave one the idea of being a little man. His hands.were white and small, his frame was fragile, his voice.was quiet and his manners were refined. He took the.greatest care of his fair silken hair and moustache and.used perfume discreetly on his handkerchief. The.half-moons of his nails were perfect and when he.smiled you caught a glimpse of a row of childish.white teeth..As he sat at his desk in the King’s Inns he thought.what changes those eight years had brought. The.friend whom he had known under a shabby and.necessitous guise had become a brilliant figure on the.London Press. He turned often from his tiresome.writing to gaze out of the office window. The glow of.a late autumn sunset covered the grass plots and.walks. It cast a shower of kindly golden dust on the.untidy nurses and decrepit old men who drowsed on.the benches; it flickered upon all the moving figures.—on the children who ran screaming along the gravel.paths and on everyone who passed through the.gardens. He watched the scene and thought of life;.and (as always happened when he thought of life) he.became sad. A gentle melancholy took possession of.him. He felt how useless it was to struggle against.fortune, this being the burden of wisdom which the.ages had bequeathed to him..He remembered the books of poetry upon his.shelves at home. He had bought them in his bachelor.days and many an evening, as he sat in the little room.off the hall, he had been tempted to take one down.from the bookshelf and read out something to his.wife. But shyness had always held him back; and so.the books had remained on their shelves. At times he.repeated lines to himself and this consoled him..When his hour had struck he stood up and took.leave of his desk and of his fellow-clerks.punctiliously. He emerged from under the feudal.arch of the King’s Inns, a neat modest figure, and.walked swiftly down Henrietta Street. The golden.sunset was waning and the air had grown sharp. A.horde of grimy children populated the street. They.stood or ran in the roadway or crawled up the steps.before the gaping doors or squatted like mice upon.the thresholds. Little Chandler gave them no thought..He picked his way deftly through all that minute life.and under the shadow of the gaunt spectral mansions.in which the old nobility of Dublin had roystered..No memory of the past touched him, for his mind.was full of a present joy..He had never been in Corless’s but he knew the.value of the name. He knew that people went there.after the theatre to eat oysters; and he had heard that.the waiters there spoke French and German..Walking swiftly by at night he had seen cabs drawn.up before the door and richly dressed ladies, escorted.by cavaliers, alight and enter quickly. They wore.noisy dresses and many wraps. Their faces were.powdered and they caught up their dresses, when.they touched earth. He had always passed without.turning his head to look. It was his habit to walk.swiftly in the street even by day and whenever he.found himself in the city late at night he hurried on.his way apprehensively and excitedly. Sometimes,.however, he courted the causes of his fear. He chose.the darkest and narrowest streets and, as he walked.boldly forward, the silence that was spread about his.footsteps troubled him, the wandering, silent figures.troubled him; and at times a sound of low fugitive.laughter made him tremble like a leaf..He turned to the right towards Capel Street..Ignatius Gallaher on the London Press! Who would.have thought it possible eight years before? Still, now.that he reviewed the past, Little Chandler could.remember many signs of future greatness in his.friend.
Which choice best summarizes the passage?
(A)A character reunites with an old friend and discovers that they cannot resume their friendship.
(B)An invitation from an old friend prompts a character to reflect on both the past and the present.
(C)A chance meeting with an old friend inspires a character to start a new life in another country.
(D)A character’s recent professional success prompts him to provide assistance to an old friend.
output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and identify the key events and themes.

1. The passage describes a character named Little Chandler who is reflecting on his old friend Gallaher.
2. Eight years ago, Little Chandler saw Gallaher off at the North Wall, and Gallaher had "got on" - meaning he had become successful.
3. Gallaher had a "travelled air" and "well-cut tweed suit", indicating he had become prosperous.
4. Little Chandler's thoughts have been focused on his upcoming meeting with Gallaher and Gallaher's invitation to the "great city of London".
5. The passage describes how Little Chandler's life has changed in the eight years since he last saw Gallaher - Gallaher has become a "brilliant figure on the London Press" while Little Chandler remains at his desk job.
6. Little Chandler feels a "gentle melancholy" as he reflects on how his life has not changed much, while Gallaher has found great success.
7. The passage does not indicate that Little Chandler and Gallaher are planning to resume their friendship or that Gallaher is providing any assistance to Little Chandler.

Based on this analysis, the choice that best summarizes the passage is:
(B) An invitation from an old friend prompts a character to reflect on both the past and the present.

The passage focuses on Little Chandler's reflections on his old friend Gallaher's success and his own life, prompted by Gallaher's invitation, rather than depicting a reunion or Gallaher providing assistance.

The.friend whom he had known under a shabby and.necessitous guise had become a brilliant figure on the.London Press. He turned often from his tiresome.writing to gaze out of the office window. The glow of.a late autumn sunset covered the grass plots and.walks. It cast a shower of kindly golden dust on the.untidy nurses and decrepit old men who drowsed on.the benches; it flickered upon all the moving figures.—on the children who ran screaming along the gravel.paths and on everyone who passed through the.gardens. He watched the scene and thought of life;.and (as always happened when he thought of life) he.became sad. A gentle melancholy took possession of.him. He felt how useless it was to struggle against.fortune, this being the burden of wisdom which the.ages had bequeathed to him..He remembered the books of poetry upon his.shelves at home. He had bought them in his bachelor.days and many an evening, as he sat in the little room.off the hall, he had been tempted to take one down.from the bookshelf and read out something to his.wife. But shyness had always held him back; and so.the books had remained on their shelves. At times he.repeated lines to himself and this consoled him..When his hour had struck he stood up and took.leave of his desk and of his fellow-clerks.punctiliously. He emerged from under the feudal.arch of the King’s Inns, a neat modest figure, and.walked swiftly down Henrietta Street. The golden.sunset was waning and the air had grown sharp. A.horde of grimy children populated the street. They.stood or ran in the roadway or crawled up the steps.before the gaping doors or squatted like mice upon.the thresholds. Little Chandler gave them no thought..He picked his way deftly through all that minute life.and under the shadow of the gaunt spectral mansions.in which the old nobility of Dublin had roystered..No memory of the past touched him, for his mind.was full of a present joy..He had never been in Corless’s but he knew the.value of the name. He knew that people went there.after the theatre to eat oysters; and he had heard that.the waiters there spoke French and German..Walking swiftly by at night he had seen cabs drawn.up before the door and richly dressed ladies, escorted.by cavaliers, alight and enter quickly. They wore.noisy dresses and many wraps. Their faces were.powdered and they caught up their dresses, when.they touched earth. He had always passed without.turning his head to look. It was his habit to walk.swiftly in the street even by day and whenever he.found himself in the city late at night he hurried on.his way apprehensively and excitedly. Sometimes,.however, he courted the causes of his fear. He chose.the darkest and narrowest streets and, as he walked.boldly forward, the silence that was spread about his.footsteps troubled him, the wandering, silent figures.troubled him; and at times a sound of low fugitive.laughter made him tremble like a leaf..He turned to the right towards Capel Street..Ignatius Gallaher on the London Press! Based on the passage, which choice best identifies a contradictory impulse in Little Chandler’s character?
(A)He fixates on a social world that he ultimately believes to be a hollow spectacle.
(B)He immerses himself in sights and sounds that strike him as ultimately frivolous.
(C)He scorns a historical era that he concedes is preferable in some ways to the present.
(D)He derives excitement from placing himself in settings he finds menacing.
output:
To solve this problem, I will carefully analyze the passage and identify the contradictory impulses in Little Chandler's character.

The passage describes Little Chandler as a refined, shy, and melancholy man who is fascinated by the success of his friend Ignatius Gallaher. It also depicts Little Chandler's ambivalent feelings towards the social world of Dublin and London.

The key evidence of a contradictory impulse in Little Chandler's character is found in the following passages:

1) "He turned often from his tiresome writing to gaze out of the office window. The glow of a late autumn sunset covered the grass plots and walks. It cast a shower of kindly golden dust on the untidy nurses and decrepit old men who drowsed on the benches; it flickered upon all the moving figures—on the children who ran screaming along the gravel paths and on everyone who passed through the gardens. He watched the scene and thought of life; and (as always happened when he thought of life) he became sad."

This shows that Little Chandler is drawn to the vibrant, lively scenes outside his office window, even as he becomes melancholy when contemplating life.

2) "Walking swiftly by at night he had seen cabs drawn up before the door and richly dressed ladies, escorted by cavaliers, alight and enter quickly. They wore noisy dresses and many wraps. Their faces were powdered and they caught up their dresses, when they touched earth. He had always passed without turning his head to look. It was his habit to walk swiftly in the street even by day and whenever he found himself in the city late at night he hurried on his way apprehensively and excitedly. Sometimes, however, he courted the causes of his fear. He chose the darkest and narrowest streets and, as he walked boldly forward, the silence that was spread about his footsteps troubled him, the wandering, silent figures troubled him; and at times a sound of low fugitive laughter made him tremble like a leaf."

This passage shows that Little Chandler is both drawn to and repulsed by the vibrant social world of Dublin and London. He is excited and apprehensive when encountering it, and even seeks out situations that he finds menacing.

Given this evidence, the best answer is (D) - He derives excitement from placing himself in settings he finds menacing. This captures the contradictory impulse in Little Chandler's character, where he is simultaneously attracted to and repelled by the lively urban environments he encounters.

(A)convey Little Chandler’s sense that hindsight has lent a degree of inevitability to Gallaher’s success.
(B)suggest the extent to which the news of Gallaher’s success has altered Little Chandler’s memory of him.

output:

The passage describes Little Chandler's thoughts and feelings as he reflects on his old friend, Ignatius Gallaher, who has become a successful journalist in London. Little Chandler remembers the time when he saw Gallaher off at the North Wall, and how Gallaher had already shown signs of success even then.
